STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 20, 2023
Julie Waldron
Cheboygan/Presque Isle County DHHS
827 S Huron ST
Cheboygan, MI 49721-2209
RE: License #: CP160201035
827 S Huron ST
Cheboygan, MI 49721-2209
Dear Ms. Waldron:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on December
1, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Douglas W Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08 Treatment Plans/PATP
The treatment plan must be completed for all children
with an open foster care program type. The initial
treatment plan must be completed for inclusion with the
child's initial DHS-441, Case Service Plan, or DHS-442,
Permanent Ward Service Plan. The treatment plan
must be reviewed and revised for inclusion with each
updated DHS-441 or DHS-442. Caseworkers must
complete the treatment plan in MISACWIS. All
requirements in this item apply to the DHS-441a,
Parent Agency Treatment Plan, and DHS-442a,
Permanent Ward Treatment Plan unless otherwise
specified.
Four files and 16 service plans were reviewed. Two of 16 Service Plans/PATPs
reviewed were not uploaded. A Service Plan/PATP dated July 27, 2022, was not
uploaded. A second Service Plan/PATP dated April 28, 2022, was not uploaded.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for
the following: • Completing the DHS-1105, Family
Team Meeting Report, checking it for accuracy,
identifying areas needing follow-up, and recording the
outcome data. • Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, to all participants (in person and by
phone), legal parents, and casework supervisor. These
documents must also be uploaded into the electronic
case management record. The caseworker must enter
the FTM information in the electronic case
management record using the FTM hyperlink within
seven business days of the FTM.
3

Four files and 16 FTM’s were reviewed. Two of 16 FTM’s conducted did not have
the DHHS-1105 completed. An FTM dated January 21, 2022, did not have a
completed DHHS-1105. A second FTM dated July 22, 2022, did not have a
c ompleted DHHS-1105.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAVFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAVFC youth, when
living in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an apartment,
are then considered to be in independent living and therefore independent living rules
apply. The independent living rules do not apply to YAVFC youth living with a relative,
in a foster home, or in a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
An approved corrective action plan was received on September 29, 2021, in
response to rule violations established during the renewal inspection completed on
August 31, 2021. The current inspection did not establish any repeat violations
indicating that the agency CAP was sucessful in preventing repeat vioplations. There
were no complaints against the agency during the licensing period.
Chief Administrators Assessment:
The Chief Administrators assessment was reviewed and was found to be thorough.
The assessment identified systemic factors that impacted the agency in the past
year. They are as follows: The agency was short staffed for a period of time which
posed challenges for the foster care team. The report also stated that the ongoing
effects of the COVID pandemic has made it difficult to obtain dental appointments as
dental offices are scheduling appointments very far in advance. Travel time to make
face-to-face visits with foster children also is a challenge but the report states
compliance with face-to-face visits is very high. The report further indicates that
worker meetings with parents can be a challenge at times due to an unwilling or non-
participatory parent. The assessment also addressed rule violations established
during the renewal inspection in 2021 and the agency efforts to prevent future
violations.
4

Interviews:
Staff reported that they like working for the agency and feel they have a supportive
team. Staff stated further that their supervisor as well as the Chief Administrator are
knowledgeable and supportive. Staff reported that inadequate staffing has presented
challenges at times however the team comes together to overcome obstacles.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The Field Analyst identified two safety alerts while visiting agency homes.
They are as follows:
Safety Alert #1. This safety alert was generated on August 17, 2022, and involved
bows and arrows which were not stored securely and also guns and ammunition that
were not kept locked in separate locations. The agency responded and resolution
was obtained on August 18, 2022. Photos were provided and accompanied the
resolution.
Safety Alert #2. This safety alert was generated on August 15, 2022, and involved
the lack of an installed carbon monoxide detector in the foster home. Resolution was
achieved on August 16, 2022. A photo of the installed detector was provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
January 9, 2023
______________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 20, 2023

Kari Muntean Date
